circumstances: The airplane was owned by the American writer Laura Ingalls who was at controls at the time of the accident. She was carrying isolationist leaflets for aerial dispersal. On the fuselage was painted the mention 'No A.E.F.', meaning no American Expeditionary Force (in Europe). Upon landing, the airplane lost its right main gear, went out of control and came to rest on its nose, broken in two. The pilot was slightly injured.
probable_cause: According to the NASM, due to normal wear & tear, the right main gear failed upon touchdown (normal landing). The right wing dragged and all gear failed. The engine torn loose and the fuselage broke in two at #4 bulkhead ring.
